cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in hydrogen-exposed steel, often near welds.

members.entity_description: A type of cracking in steel caused by the presence of hydrogen and stress, often near welds, characterized by cracks aligned nearly perpendicular to stress.
Stepwise internal cracks in metal connecting hydrogen blisters, occurring without external stress.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in sulfide and acid environments.

members.entity_description: A form of hydrogen embrittlement that occurs in metals exposed to sulfide environments.
A type of corrosion that affects austenitic stainless steels and other austenitic alloys during shutdowns.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to environmental factors, including wet H2S environments and carbon steel weldments.

members.entity_description: Cracking of pressure vessels in environments containing wet hydrogen sulfide.

members.entity_name: environmental cracking of carbon steel weldments
members.entity_description: Cracking that occurs in carbon steel weldments due to environmental factors in corrosive environments.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking due to stress and corrosive environments.

members.entity_description: A failure mechanism where cracks form in a material due to the combined effects of tensile stress and a corrosive environment.
Cracking of materials facilitated by environmental conditions.

cluster_classes.class_description: Mechanisms causing material degradation, including mechanical, metallurgical, and thickness loss processes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The mechanisms are divided into sections: a) Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure, b) Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness.

members.entity_description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes in various industries.

members.entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness
members.entity_description: A damage mechanism involving the reduction of material thickness, either uniformly or in specific areas.

splits.name: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure Mechanisms
splits.description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes.

splits.name: Thickness Loss Mechanisms
splits.description: Mechanisms involving uniform or localized loss of material thickness.

args.justification: ClsC_26300b9e is overloaded, grouping unrelated mechanisms (mechanical/metallurgical failure vs. thickness loss); splitting improves schema coherence.

args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
args.justification: Assigning a more precise Class_Group to connect hydrogen-related cracking with other environmental cracking classes.

args.new_name: Sulfide and Acid Stress Cracking Mechanisms
args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
args.justification: Assigning to the same Class_Group as other environmental cracking mechanisms for schema consistency.

args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to environmental factors, including wet H2S environments and carbon steel weldments.
args.justification: Class_Group assignment aligns with other classes focused on environmental cracking.

args.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
args.justification: Assigning to the same Class_Group as other environmental cracking classes for schema connectivity.

args.new_description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes.
args.justification: Assigning a distinct Class_Group for mechanical/metallurgical failure mechanisms, separate from environmental cracking.

args.new_description: Mechanisms involving uniform or localized loss of material thickness.
args.justification: Assigning a distinct Class_Group for thickness loss mechanisms, as this is a different degradation mode from cracking or mechanical failure.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsC_26300b9e is overloaded, grouping unrelated mechanisms (mechanical/metallurgical failure vs. thickness loss); splitting improves schema coherence.

executed_decisions.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning a more precise Class_Group to connect hydrogen-related cracking with other environmental cracking classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning to the same Class_Group as other environmental cracking mechanisms for schema consistency.

executed_decisions.justification: Class_Group assignment aligns with other classes focused on environmental cracking.

executed_decisions.justification: Assigning to the same Class_Group as other environmental cracking classes for schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.new_description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes.
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning a distinct Class_Group for mechanical/metallurgical failure mechanisms, separate from environmental cracking.

executed_decisions.new_description: Mechanisms involving uniform or localized loss of material thickness.
executed_decisions.justification: Assigning a distinct Class_Group for thickness loss mechanisms, as this is a different degradation mode from cracking or mechanical failure.
